comments.commentBody:
Dr. K,

The evidence presented by Len Charlap on Balanced Budgets and Depressions worked up Frederick C. Thayer in The American Journal of Economics and Sociology would seem to convince the most hard headed economists that there is a high likelihood that for a sovereign nation to seek to balance budgets by cutting government spending can have negative economic consequences. It would also seem rational that we would not reduce spending during a period of high unemployment & pretty good evidence that the US economy was not at capacity. Furthermore, the economy has been slowing for three decades, since the outrageous oil price hikes of the 1970's.

I can remember the oil misery well, saw inflation do its thing in response, & watched Paul Volcker demonstrate the power of Fed monetary actions to bring a screeching halt to inflation.

Therefore, It seems to me that the last recession experience &,most of all, the extremely slow recovery that followed should tell political leaders, both conservatives and moderates, that there is no upside to austerity during a an economic recovery, that is teetering on price deflation, & keeps labor in its place with 3 applicants for every job, I have friends who tell me that it is inevitable that our wages must come in line with the global labor pool at even lower real wages than we currently have.

Bottom line: we have allowed our brand of mythic capitalism to rob us blind and concentrate the returns of cheap labor in very few hands.
I woulda thought the change in China gov policy to open up the country for trade and exploit export demand played a major role.  Guess not.
Right. China's economy got better simply because it forced people to stop having babies. Opening itself to the outside world for trade and investment had nothing to do with it.

A correction to my earlier post: According to Noah Smith:

"And the frequency of the paradigm crises in macroeconomics - one in the 1930s, another in the 1970s, and another in the 2010s - shows how few solid conclusions we can really draw from macroeconomic data (Note: On this point, see update below)."

I think this skepticism is justified, and in a later update, Noah Smith goes on to explain why evidence does not necessarily corroborate New Keynesian models.

Yes, Krugman is right that monetary policy can have a major impact on the real economy and that wages are sticky. But the models he presents in this blog miss an analysis of the other economic forces that can effect unemployment for example.

Both fresh and salt water economists seem focused on the business cycle. Yet macroeconomics should also provide information on the long term to help guide long term policy.

Like astronomers, economists have to wait for countries to set up their experiments for them. Such an experiment occurred in China during 1976-2014.

In 1976, Mao died and China reversed Mao's pro-natalist policies shortly thereafter. Under Deng Xiaoping and his successors, China introduced a one-child policy which drastically cut down population growth within China.

How did that work out? China now produces more autos than the US, has high-speed rail connecting Beijing to Guangzhou,and excels in may other areas.

China cut the supply of people, instead of increasing aggregate demand.

A dead woman who's own personal and that of her families wishes were not honored by the state?
To be born from a dead woman who was dishonored by a theocracy?
To be born from a dead woman into a state, texas, which will do anything to keep THIS fetus alive, AND will not provide health care for the 25% of the poorer children who are alive?
I think he has a legal argument to refuse payment to the hospital.  They created the problem.  They can eat the charges.

the issue is that the current government intervention is establishing a playing field that is not level, it's pandering to the powerful. nothing new right? but at the very least, leave some meat on the bone for individuals to participate, innovate, and hopefully thrive. it's not about hand-outs, it's about not allowing those with the most chips dictate all the hands.
Atomic number, I think.. Helium.  That type of clue gets me every time.
I am stumped by that too, and asked for help. Maybe someone can explain it to us??
What the heck is "atno?" I do not understand the 49 down clue at all! The rest of the puzzle was clever and fun.

"The three tenets of Libertarianism:
1. Your not the boss of me.
2. It's mine! You can't have any.
3. Look Mommy! I did it all by myself."

Better (and more accurate) list:

1. You are free to do whatever you want as long as you don't cause harm to another person or their property.
2. There is a difference between a crime and a sin; government should be involved in the former and not the latter.
3. The basic responsibilities of any government is to protect life and private property.

The debate that whether demand or supply drives economy has  the surreal quality Did any economist of this debate ask any businessmen, big or small about the issue. Earlier in this blog one business owner commented that he never worries about his supply. The demands determines his business plan. Keynes theorized the economic system and also invested in real world, smelling the real world. Economists of the academia, go out to the corner stores  and ask  the shop keeper, ask him what ails his business.
Colorado has always been about get-rich-quick schemes. Why would this be any different?

The idea was to stop destroying the lives of young men of color by locking them in prisons for possessing small amounts of marijuana. Now every grifter from Grand Junction to Sterling is hatching a get-rich scheme around legally getting stoned. Just another lottery ticket in the land of the corporations. One more hail Mary before the bank forecloses on your house and you, too, slip below the poverty line.

Sales require customers; customers require income. Just as the folks at Davos this past week are starting to clue in that Climate change is affecting their bottom line, *eventually* they will figure out what Henry Ford did: pay your workers enough to afford to buy your product. For many industries, that will mean a living wage.
Thank you! It was driving me nuts!

Arrrgh! And here I was a chemistry major... Thank you for that enlightenment!

I almost completed the whole puzzle without any outside help, but I got stuck down in the bottom center because I had never heard of ED WOOD, ELOGE or EWEN, and I had put TPS for DPS, because I think of a double play as fairly routine, and not a feat like a triple play. But Googling for ED WOOD gave me the rest, with a few judicious uses of the "check word" function.

Fun puzzle!
Barbara:  That one drove me crazy also, until it clicked.  He is not the pronoun, but the symbol for Helium.  The Atomic Number (ATNO) of Helium is 2.
True, we (99%) can vote for those with relevant ideology and decency, not funding, fame and tv commercials.

I've been a Mac person since I was issued an SE at my office in 1987. I've lost count of the Macs I've owned but my new iMac may be number six, not counting an iPhone. I first bought Apple stock as a gesture of solidarity when they seemed endangered because I was scared of being forced to use PCs. As it is, I have used PCs at various workplaces for years and have never warmed up to them.

Macs cost more because they are (at least in some ways) better — easier to use, less susceptible to malware, prettier. Artists love them because the visual experience is so much nicer — subtler colors, more attractive icons, windows and fonts, more ways to design one's own desktop. For many of us, the computer screen is our environment. That's what we look at all day. Windows doesn't make that a pleasant experience.

The loss of Steve Jobs will be increasingly felt. The new iPhone operating system contains features he never would have allowed, such as garish lime green accents and an idiotic redesign of the calendar. But Macs are still great and I trust they will remain great for some time to come.
I'm afraid of Justin Bieber, and I'm almost as old as you.

"we all thought we were intellectuals"

We all thought we were funnier, more clever, much more insightful when we drank or smoked. I had to give that up (mostly) when three young kids became my priority. I sat in sometimes with my old friends, but didn't partake with them because I had other things to do next. I discovered while listening to it without the benefit of drinking or smoking that we were not funnier, more clever, or more insightful. In fact, we were all kind of stupid. But you know what? That didn't matter. We had fun. That was the point. We had a really good time doing it, and we did not really need to be star comics or world class thinkers. There's a time and place for all that, and it's a good thing too.

@EricR
Remember Errol Flynn?

Takes me back to my days in North Beach, listening to poets, and sharing a toke or two.
There was always a party around Telegraph Hill, and we all thought we were intellectuals, discussing the ways of the world. They called us Beatinics then, we were a bit older than the later Hippies, and not quite so overt.

There was Benny Bufanao the sculptor, and Lawrence Ferlinghetti the poet among others. You could hear him at the City Lights Bookstore, he was one of the owners. I was just a lurker in those days, but my experiences there are behind a lot of my comments here these days.

As usual the politicians and conservative media saw us as a threat, so it is surprising how many went on to bring needed changes to society.

The uptight society manages to find something in each generation to create a fear about. Maybe a good joint is what they need, to help them cope with modern times.
hm - You should read the Constitution. especially the parts about "General Welfare" and then read the SCOTUS decsion helvring v davis.
Only eight to start with??!  If I have eight to start with, it's a very easy puzzle and I know it's going to solve easily!  My hat is off to you.

Hooray for a really tough puzzle this week! At least it was for me. I was only able to answer eight clues right off the bat. A pretty good start, but not quite enough to make this one a walk in the park.

Clever clues and an unexpected quotation solution made for an extra fun solve this week.

Thanks, EC and HR!

P.S. -- Silk from goat's milk? Ew! (And if it had been silk from sheep's milk I would have said ewe!)

I hope by "ready to help the country, and the people, without debt to corporations, and with a sense of strength, as well as compassion" you don't mean the economically-illiterate, anti-government, Koch-backed flip-flopper who reversed deeply ideological positions for political gain sham of a politician known as "Rand Paul"
Actually, Glenn Beck did try to start a libertarian colony in Idaho...
Can't wait to see the movie version!
We have that now in the "progressive" era. Without the discipline of a free market, poorly run banks and car companies are bailed out and survive to mooch off of us another day.

MIke,

You show up in al the right places. Hi Maureen. Party time?

Meanwhile, what's going on between consenting adults in Denver will soon be happening back in the U.S.S.R. Just you watch.
Don't forget Senator Coburn.

They're body mechanics and plumbers and many think their years of vocational education have rendered them experts on everything.

They're often clever, but how many Physicians are truly wise?

Actually that is being sold now to the public. Actually I think it is the congress people who get paid way too much, with a retirement package that runs in the six figures, they get perks that made all of them millionaires , golden health care system ( paid with our taxes). We really should rid ourselves of these selfish perks. The public should be able to vote whether they should have the same SS check and minimal pensions. Congress, Senators, should not be able to listen to thousands of lobbyists, to benefit special interests. One lobbyist per special interest, not two hundred per congress person. Corporations should be forced to refrain from paying millions in adds to get their puppet congress person elected to benefit them but NOT the public. After al,l it is mostly the working person who pays the taxes. Corporate tax rates went down from an average 19% prior to Reagan down to 6.9% sometimes 0%, yet they have a right to be voting? This is the country we have here?

I've always thought that doctors are among the most highly
overrated and overpaid people in the country. The thing I like about Rand Paul is that he helps prove this almost
every time he opens his mouth.

One thing that puts the US in an uncompetitive position is our expensive insistence on being the World Policeman, often on behalf of ungrateful "allies". Big businesses get rich from cushy defense contracts instead of making world competitive products. Rand Paul is one of the few daring to challenge this status quo.

You completely failed to close the case.  But if you do sit down with this "straight shooter," you can explain to him what "plagiarism" means.  You might have to start with "honesty."  Lots of "straight shooters" never grasp that concept.

Most Americans don't have the luxury of making a living as poets, artists or intellectuals, who apparently get to spend a lot of time navel gazing. Most people have to show up every day, often at the same time each day, and get to work.

Is pot that different from qat or coca leaves which are the drugs of choice in other countries? I don't see that regular use of those drugs has necessarily made the world a better place.

Maybe it's useful for people who are too overly ambitious, but I think most people are actually not overly ambitious.
